title.sub: From pint-sized prodigy to controversial character

naissance.caption: Birth
naissance.text: Marie Élisabeth Joly is born in Versailles to Thomas Joly, a hardware merchant in Paris and dancer with the Comédie-Française, and to Élisabeth Vivien Joly, a dancer with the Comédie-Française.

enfant.caption: Childhood debut
enfant.text: At the age of 7, Joly makes her first appearance onstage at the Comédie-Française, playing Louison in Molière’s Le Malade imaginaire. The casting record identifies her as “daughter of the dancer”.

roles.caption: Childhood roles
roles.text: This document summarizes the roles played by Joly between July 1769 and March 1770, as well as the payment due to her for these performances.

debut.caption: Adult debut
debut.text: At nearly 20 years old, Joly receives her adult debut order to allow the Comédie to “judge her talents”.

reception.caption: Opinions on her reception
reception.text: Following her debut, the Comédie’s assembly discusses Joly’s formal admittance to the troupe. Mrs. Bellecour maintains that a two-year probation period is standard and still necessary in this case. Mr. Préville, however, agrees with the Maréchal de Duras that Joly should be admitted to the troupe right away. This opinion prevailed, with ten members in agreement and only six in opposition.

essai.caption: Reception
essai.text: Following the debate surrounding her admission to the troupe, Mlle Joly is received by the Comédie Française with a salary of 2000 pounds each year.

refus.caption: Refusal to perform
refus.text: The Duke of Duras advises the assembly of the Comédie on Joly’s refusal to perform; while she has proven her goodwill in the past, he considers her refusal to perform ridiculous and worthy of punishment, considering the Comédie may have had to close had Ms. Ollivier not been ready to perform in her place. However, he concludes that her behaviour will be overlooked on this occasion, considering the goodwill she has demonstrated in the past.

augmentation.caption: Request for a raise
augmentation.text: Joly requests a pay raise to cover her necessary expenses. She alludes to the everyday expenses that result from her acting career, and reminds the troupe of her dedication and hard work, even for roles that are not within her standard repertoire, as these require her to purchase additional costumes. The committee agrees with her request, and forwards her letter to the Duke of Duras with their support.

suspension.caption: Suspension from the assembly
suspension.text: On the basis of numerous complaints made about Joly, Mrs. Bellecour proposes that Joly be suspended from all assemblies but those for repertoire. Mr. Dugazon agrees, with the addition of restricting her ability to grant entry to the audience. All others are in agreement with Mrs. Bellecour, and the committee concludes that she will be suspended from assemblies for six months.

replique.caption: Declaration of innocence
replique.text: In response to her suspension, Joly maintains her innocence, insisting that the complaints made about her are false.

prison.caption: Imprisonment during the Revolution
prison.text: Imprisoned with the other Comédiens du Roi in 1793, writes to an unknown recipient from the Saint Pélagie prison about the injustice of her imprisonment.

mort.caption: Death
mort.text: Joly passes away in Paris at the age of 37, and is buried at Sousmont-Saint-Quentin.

naissance.caption: Birth
naissance.text: Born in Paris, Bellecour initially pursues the visual arts, destined to be a painter like his father Colson. After studying under Carle Van Loo, he instead decides on a career in acting and makes his theatrical debut with the troupe in Besançon. While there, he is said to have met and been mentored by M. Préville, which in turn led to his admission to the Comédie-Française at the apparent behest of the Duke of Richelieu and Madame de Pompadour. (Lyonnet)

reception.caption: Admission to the Comédie-Française
reception.text: Bellecour is officially inducted into the Comédie-Française on December 20, 1750 - the same year as his later famous colleague Le Kain, who had been admitted just a few months earlier on September 14. On November 2, 1752, he received formal permission to pursue a permanent appointment with the company. While he began his career as an actor bound to neither tragedy nor comedy, he later specialised in, and performed almost exclusively, the latter.

roles.caption: Bellecour's roles
roles.text: This document summarizes the roles Mr. Bellecour plays; the list is undated, but mentions that he has been performing for 5 years, so it dates from approximately 1756–1757. This list demonstrates the high number of roles for which this actor was responsible, and it speaks to the process of specialisation which led Bellecour to take on exclusively comedic roles later in his career. For the period of 1765-1791, Bellecour played 174 different roles, including the debut performances of 15 new plays.

retraite.caption: Attempted retirement
retraite.text: After nearly twenty years of service to the Comédie-Francaise, Mr. Bellecour, deeply unwell, requests to retire, but is ordered by the Duke of Richelieu to remain an active member of the troupe, the latter proposing an alternate arrangement of three months of leave granted to allow him to cope with his health issues. The court's right to refuse his request is one of a collection of regulations published in 1757.

sante.caption: Health troubles
sante.text: 1773 is a year littered with letters detailing the actor’s failing health. These missives, originally written to his fellow troupe members, not only show how his administrative duties took as much of a daily toll as his on-stage responsibilities, but also reflect the attention paid to the body in actors’ correspondence, Bellecour being one of many examples of the importance given to matters of illness and other physical failings.

repertoire.caption: Reflections on repertory
repertoire.text: During the same year, Bellecour demonstrates his engagement in the process of selecting the Comédie’s repertory, from a strategic and entrepreneurial perspective as well as  from a critical perspective. This letter from December 1773 shows Bellecour’s lucid reflections on issues of staging and scheduling constraints involved in choosing the two plays performed each evening.

mediateur.caption: Conflict mediator
mediateur.text: Several letters demonstrate Bellecour’s role as a mediator within the troupe. Bellecour writes to the Comédie to settle a disagreement with Mr. Reymond, who was angry about an issue of finances. Bellecour advises his colleagues to treat Reymond with kindness, now that he has calmed down. He once again invokes the importance of justice and equality when the troupe makes these collective decisions in a letter from August 28, 1776 regarding an incident involving Mr. Dalainval; Bellecour implores his colleagues to “examine this affair with due care and equity”.

pensions.caption: Pensions
pensions.text: Having received a threatening letter, Bellecour shares it with an unknown recipient - a “protector” according to editorial notes- along with his opinion of the situation. He is unbothered by the threats, but mentions the fact that he receives a pension significantly lower than those of his colleagues. Lekain, who started with the troupe mere months before him, earns 1500 pounds more. Others of his letters show that Bellecour, in more general terms, saw matters of injustice to be of great importance, and that the troupe’s social and moral ideals were far from aligned with his own.

lekain.caption: Death of Lekain
lekain.text: Bellecour writes to the Assembly shortly after Lekain’s death. He is overwhelmed by the death of his dear friend who he believed a cornerstone of the Comédie-Française. Bellecour concludes that his own career should also come to an end, and fragile in his grief, expresses his heartfelt love for the troupe.

cour.caption: A troupe at the royal court?
cour.text: Tasked with investigating the possibility of forming a dedicated theatre troupe for the royal court, Mr. Bellecour reports on his findings. He worries that a new troupe could cause the existing troupe of the Comédie-Française to become obsolete. The fact that he was entrusted with this important task is evidence of the respect held for Bellecour by the officials of the Comédie-Française.

malheur.caption: Disenchantment
malheur.text: In his final year with the Comédie-Française, Bellecour, finally expresses his disappointment in the treatment he received over the course of his career. He spent 27 years supporting and making sacrifices for his community; he does not feel at all appreciated, and once again criticizes the petty rivalries and jealousies between his colleagues.

mort.caption: Obituary
mort.text: Following Bellecour’s death, an unflattering obituary is printed in the Mercure de France. Enraged by this gross misrepresentation of his friend and colleague, Préville writes to Mr. La Harpe - the editor in chief - to complain and respond in kind to aspersions cast. This exchange shows the importance of the press in constructing an actor’s public image, but also the genuine friendship between members of the troupe.

title.sub: The Don Juan of the wings

debut.content: The formal debut process concerns only those actors wishing to eventually become full members of the troupe. A candidate must obtain permission to debut from the premiers gentilshommes.

para.one: This authorisation, which does not amount to reception by the company, permits the candidate to appear for the first on the stage in a public performance as part of the Comédie-Française. This is referred to as ‘making their debut’. These debuts are systematically announced, and the public, eager to discover new talent and appreciative of the heightened stakes, flock to the performances in question.
para.three: December 23, 1772, debut of Mademoiselle Raucourt, a student of Brizard
para.four: In rare cases, the debuts are not publicly announced but instead recorded in the daily casting registers.
para.five: Attendees, most notably the groundlings, enthusiastically make their opinions known, applauding or booing the new candidates throughout the performance.
para.eight: If the debut goes well, and it is believed that the actor could be an asset to the troupe, they are formally received into the company and given a starting salary.
para.nine: An actor or actress’s debut has the potential to be not merely an administrative formality, but also a metaphorical battleground for proponents - internal or external to the company-  of a certain aesthetic tendency or political belief; we know that a given candidate is a supporter of a particular party, and that this plays into the reason for their debut. These ulterior motives draw to the debut performances a different tier of partisan spectators, there to support or discredit the candidate in an effort to further their cause.
para.twelve: The formal permission to debut is the first step to becoming a full member of the troupe. In general, the associated documents are rarely restrictive or precise with regards to the kinds of roles the candidate is permitted to play. Common wording such as ‘which ever roles suit them’, ‘comedic or tragic roles’, or even ‘wherever they may be of use’ demonstrates how an actor’s debut period was a chance for them to explore their range. However, in certain cases it is specified that a candidate is to act as a double to one or several existing members of the troupe, or inherit the roles traditionally played by a retiring member. The latter is the case of Préville, who replaced Poisson. There appears to be little formal company legislation pertaining to the period of debut; the receipts and casting registers do however show that some actors, following an unsuccessful first debut, are able to return for a second attempt.
para.fourteen: The official probationary period appears chronologically later in the company archives. In the 1760’s, the associated documents specify several key elements, notably specific information pertaining to the specialisation of certain actors or actresses, precise beyond what was established during their period of debut. It is also during this secondary step that the actors received their pensions, therefore promoting them to the status of ‘pensionnaire’, which is a title denoting an association with the troupe, though not full membership, that was - as a general rule - held for a minimum of two years. The time it takes an actor to transition from ‘pensionnaire’ to full society member varies, but generally follows the aforementioned rule, lasting between one and two years. However, there are cases where this progression occurs over a much longer period, as with Bellemont, who despite his ubiquitous presence on stage, remains  a ‘pensionnaire’ for 11 years before being properly inducted into the troupe.

contrast.title: The Bellecours: a study in opposites
contrast.content: Despite M. and Mme Bellecour’s nearly three decades of marriage and working together at the Comédie-Française, the archival documents of the theatre present the couple as two contrasting personalities. M. Bellecour is known for his kindness and his peacemaking, and while he bitterly denounces some of his colleagues’ decisions in his final years, he remains a voice of reason within the troupe. Mme Bellecour, on the other hand, experiences more personal conflict with her fellow actors. A letter she writes to the Assembly on October 5, 1780 in regard to an “dishonest scene” caused by Mlle La Chassaigne shows Mme Bellecour acknowledging her own impetuous character.
